slides.title: Configuring Search
slides.ocrText: Configuring Search

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe how Guidewire applications enable
users to search for entities

« Extend SearchCriteria entities

* Modify ClaimCenter search screens

• Modify contact search

slides.title: ClaimCenter enables two kinds of search
slides.originalNotes:
ClaimCenter enables two kinds of search
ClaimCenter provides search capabilities for many of the most important entities in the application. In addition, with integration to an address book (such as Guidewire Contact Manager), you can search for preferred service providers. The mechanism behind this search capability is a bit complex, and that's what we’re going to study in this lesson.
slides.notes:
ClaimCenter enables two kinds of search
ClaimCenter provides search capabilities for many of the most important entities in the application. In addition, with integration to an address book (such as Guidewire Contact Manager), you can search for preferred service providers. The mechanism behind this search capability is a bit complex, and that's what we’re going to study in this lesson.
slides.ocrText:
| ClaimCenter enables two kinds of search Gi

• Search within ClaimCenter * Vendor/contact search
* Claims, Activities, Checks, Recoveries, * Searches address book application
Bulk Invoices, Users, Groups * ContactManager or third-party application
+ Vendors and other contacts

* Related to service requests

slides.title: Search within ClaimCenter
slides.originalNotes:
Search within ClaimCenter
A search within ClaimCenter has three main steps.
First, the user enters search criteria on the search screen. Every field on the search screen is a criterion that can be searched om
Then, ClaimCenter combines these criteria into a SearchCriteria object. This is a virtual object that is not stored in the database. Rather, it is used programmatically to create a SQL search that is then submitted to the ClaimCenter database.

The database is searched on those criteria, and only those criteria, which the user entered, and results are returned to the ClaimCenter server, which displays them in the search results list.
slides.notes:
Search within ClaimCenter
A search within ClaimCenter has three main steps.
First, the user enters search criteria on the search screen. Every field on the search screen is a criterion that can be searched om
Then, ClaimCenter combines these criteria into a SearchCriteria object. This is a virtual object that is not stored in the database. Rather, it is used programmatically to create a SQL search that is then submitted to the ClaimCenter database.

The database is searched on those criteria, and only those criteria, which the user entered, and results are returned to the ClaimCenter server, which displays them in the search results list.
slides.ocrText:
Search within ClaimCenter Gi

• ClaimCenter server creates a SearchCriteria object from choices in the Ul

• Uses the SearchCriteria object to query the database

ClaimCenter UI ClaimCenter Server : 4 ClaimCenter Database

slides.title: Vendor or contact search
slides.originalNotes:
Vendor or contact search
A search for a vendor has a similar structure with an additional step.
After creating the SearchCriteria object, ClaimCenter uses Web Services to pass the criteria to the Address Book application, such as Contact Manager, which then forms a SQL query of its database. The Address Book returns the results to ClaimCenter via Web Services, and ClaimCenter, once again, formats the results for display.
slides.notes:
Vendor or contact search
A search for a vendor has a similar structure with an additional step.
After creating the SearchCriteria object, ClaimCenter uses Web Services to pass the criteria to the Address Book application, such as Contact Manager, which then forms a SQL query of its database. The Address Book returns the results to ClaimCenter via Web Services, and ClaimCenter, once again, formats the results for display.
slides.ocrText:
Vendor or contact search G
* ClaimCenter server forms a SearchCriteria object from choices in the Ul
• Extracts search terms from SearchCriteria object

• Passes search terms to address book application via Web Services

slides.title: Search criteria object
slides.originalNotes:
Search criteria object
The ClaimCenter search criteria object is a virtual object, meaning that there is no underlying table, and it cannot be stored in the ClaimCenter database. It is created on the fly for each search — users cannot save •favorite“ searches.
Note: In Contact Manager, the search criteria is a areal" entity — in fact, one of several entities, such as ABContactSearchCriteria
slides.notes:
Search criteria object
The ClaimCenter search criteria object is a virtual object, meaning that there is no underlying table, and it cannot be stored in the ClaimCenter database. It is created on the fly for each search — users cannot save •favorite“ searches.
Note: In Contact Manager, the search criteria is a areal" entity — in fact, one of several entities, such as ABContactSearchCriteria
slides.ocrText:
| Search criteria object Gi

• Virtual, non-persistent entity with no underlying database table
• Virtual fields match actual fields in target database

. Implemented by file configuration/config/search/search-config. xml

slides.title: search-config.xml
slides.originalNotes:
search-config.xml
Search criteria are defined in an XML file called search-configxml.
All search criteria are defined as sub-elements of a single SearchConfig element.
There can only be one
SearchConfig element in a given ClaimCenter implementation.
Creating an additional
SearchConfig element is not supported by Guidewire and will result in unexpected (and probably unwanted) application behavior.
The search-config.xml file is found at
 .]configuration/config/search/
slides.notes:
search-config.xml
Search criteria are defined in an XML file called search-configxml.
All search criteria are defined as sub-elements of a single SearchConfig element.
There can only be one
SearchConfig element in a given ClaimCenter implementation.
Creating an additional
SearchConfig element is not supported by Guidewire and will result in unexpected (and probably unwanted) application behavior.
The search-config.xml file is found at
 .]configuration/config/search/
slides.ocrText:
| search-config.xml Gi

• Defines all searches that can be performed in ClaimCenter

* Consists of one SearchConfig element and numerous sub-elements

tes Search-config.xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<SearchConfig
amlns :xsi="http: //www.w3.org/2001/xMLSchema-instance"
xsi :noNamespaceSchemaLocation="search-config.xsd"
version="1">

• IMPORTANT: DO NOT CREATE ADDITIONAL SearchConfig TAGS
* This is NOT supported by Guidewire

slides.title: search-config.xml elements
slides.originalNotes:
search-config.xml elements
As just stated, one SearchConfig element defines the full range of search criteria for the entire application.
The sub-elements will be discussed in tum.
slides.notes:
search-config.xml elements
As just stated, one SearchConfig element defines the full range of search criteria for the entire application.
The sub-elements will be discussed in tum.
slides.ocrText:
| search-config.xml elements Gi

* SearchConfig: Defines the search criteria available in the application
* CriteriaDef: Specifies the mapping from one search criteria entity to the target
entity on which to search

* Criterion: Specifies matching between a column (field) on the search criteria entity and the
target entity

+ Use only to match values in a single column of the same type in the target entity

* CriterionChoice: Defines specialized properties in the search criteria that can match
against a number of target fields

* Option: Describes a single choice within a CriterionChoice definition

* ArrayCriterion: Specifies that the search query uses a simple join against an array entity

slides.title: CriteriaDef sub-element
slides.originalNotes:
Criteria Def sub-element
CriteriaDef is a sub-element of SearchConfig. It has two properties: a name and a target entity; it defines the ability to search for instances of the target entity.
CriteriaDef has several sub- elements which will be discussed in turn.
The important thing to remember is that Guidewire provides a fixed set of CriteriaDefs. Adding CriteriaDefs is not supported and may result in unwantedapplication behavior. Removing a CriteriaDef is possible, but not recommended. But you can edit, add, and delete the Criterion, CriterionChoice, and subelements
slides.notes:
Criteria Def sub-element
CriteriaDef is a sub-element of SearchConfig. It has two properties: a name and a target entity; it defines the ability to search for instances of the target entity.
CriteriaDef has several sub- elements which will be discussed in turn.
The important thing to remember is that Guidewire provides a fixed set of CriteriaDefs. Adding CriteriaDefs is not supported and may result in unwantedapplication behavior. Removing a CriteriaDef is possible, but not recommended. But you can edit, add, and delete the Criterion, CriterionChoice, and subelements
slides.ocrText:
| CriteriaDef sub-element Gi

Defines a mapping between a key data entity and a search criteria entity

Basic syntax:
<CriteriaDef entity="name" targetEntity="name">
<sub-elements/>
</CriteriaDef>
Sub-elements can include criterion, CriterionChoice, and ArrayCriterion
WARNING: Guidewire does not support creation of new criteriaDef elements

WARNING: Guidewire strongly recommends not removing existing criteriaDef
elements

<CriteriaDef entity="ClaimInfoCriteria" targetEntity="ClaimInfo">
<Criterion property="ClaimNumber" matchType="eq"/>
<Criterion property="PolicyNumber" matchType="eq"/>
</CriteriaDef>

slides.title: Criterion sub-element
slides.originalNotes:
Criterion sub-element
If CriteriaDef defines what entities can be searched for, its sub- elements define what properties of a given entity can be used in search.
The Criterion element is the simplest of these. It defines the ability to search on one property (field) of the searchable entity. If the name of the property is different from the name of the searchable property of the entity, use the targetProperty tag to define the property name as it exists on the entity.
slides.notes:
Criterion sub-element
If CriteriaDef defines what entities can be searched for, its sub- elements define what properties of a given entity can be used in search.
The Criterion element is the simplest of these. It defines the ability to search on one property (field) of the searchable entity. If the name of the property is different from the name of the searchable property of the entity, use the targetProperty tag to define the property name as it exists on the entity.
slides.ocrText:
| Criterion sub-element Gi

• Defines a simple one-to-one relationship between a criteria entity attribute and a
target entity attribute
• Basic syntax:
<Criterion property="attributename"
targetProperty="attributename"
matchType=" type" />
* property is the name of the property on the criteria entity
* targetProperty is the name of the property on the target entity

* Only use if it is different from the value of property
<Criterion property="ClaimNumber" matchType="eq"/>
<Criterion property="AssignedToUser" targetProperty="AssignedUser" matchType="eq"/>
<Criterion property="CreatedByUser" targetProperty="CreateUser" matchType="eq"/>

slides.title: matchType tag
slides.originalNotes:
matchType tag
The matchType tag of the Criterion sub-element is a required tag that determines how to search on a given property of the target entity.

Four match Types are usable only for numeric values: ge means greater than or equal to, gt greater than, le less than or equal to, and It less than.

Two match Types — contains and startsWith — are usable only for string types. Contains is the most •expensiven in terms of search time and should be avoided wherever possible.

eq (meaning equals) is usable for all property types and is the only meaningful matchtype for typelist search.
slides.notes:
matchType tag
The matchType tag of the Criterion sub-element is a required tag that determines how to search on a given property of the target entity.

Four match Types are usable only for numeric values: ge means greater than or equal to, gt greater than, le less than or equal to, and It less than.

Two match Types — contains and startsWith — are usable only for string types. Contains is the most •expensiven in terms of search time and should be avoided wherever possible.

eq (meaning equals) is usable for all property types and is the only meaningful matchtype for typelist search.
slides.ocrText:
| matchType tag Gi

* matchType determines how the target property is matched to the criteria property
« Seven main choices:

* contains

<CriteriaDef entity="Address" targetEntity="Address">

sed <Criterion property="City" matchType="startsWith"/>

* ge <Criterion property="CityKanji" matchType="startsWithCaseSensitive"/>
<Criterion property="State" matchType="eq"/>

* gt <Criterion property="PostalCode" matchType="startsWith"/>
<Criterion property="Country" matchType="eq"/>

ele </CriteriaDef>

elt

* startsWith

slides.title: CriterionChoice sub-element
slides.originalNotes:
CriterionChoice sub-element
The main purpose of the CriterionChoice sub-element is to allow multiple criteria to be searched in the same screen real estate.
One possible disadvantage is that you can only search by one of these criteria at a time. So, if we had both the Loss date and the Closed date, we could only search on one of them.
slides.notes:
CriterionChoice sub-element
The main purpose of the CriterionChoice sub-element is to allow multiple criteria to be searched in the same screen real estate.
One possible disadvantage is that you can only search by one of these criteria at a time. So, if we had both the Loss date and the Closed date, we could only search on one of them.
slides.ocrText:
| CriterionChoice sub-element Gi

• Allows a single criterion to match against one of several columns in the target, as
chosen by the user

« For example, the Date criterionChoice element on the Advanced Claim Search screen

allows users to search for one date: the Loss date, the Reported date, the Closed date, or the
Creation date

* Basic syntax:

<CriterionChoice property="attributename"

init ="valueOrExpression"> Search For Date

Loss date
<option label="displaykey"

<none>

targetProperty="targetColumn"/>
. . . Reported date
</CriterionChoice> Closed date

* May have one or more option elements | Creation date _|

slides.title: CriterionChoice sub-element example:
slides.originalNotes:
CriterionChoice sub-element example: DateCriterionChoice
The Option sub-elements determine what can be searched for.
The label tags are display keys that determine what is displayed in the chooser. The targetProperty tags determine what field of the search entity is searched on.
slides.notes:
CriterionChoice sub-element example: DateCriterionChoice
The Option sub-elements determine what can be searched for.
The label tags are display keys that determine what is displayed in the chooser. The targetProperty tags determine what field of the search entity is searched on.
slides.ocrText:
CriterionChoice sub-element example: Gi
DateCriterionChoice

<CriterionChoice property="DateCriterionChoice"
init="DateCriterionChoice.SearchType = TC_CLAIM; DateCriterionChoice.DateSearchType =

TC_FROMLIST; DateCriterionChoice.DateRangeChoice = TC_N365; DateCriterionChoice.ChosenOption =
&quot ;Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.LossDate&quot ;">

<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.LossDate" targetProperty="LossDate"/>

<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.ReportedDate" targetProperty="ReportedDate"/>

<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.CloseDate" targetProperty="CloseDate"/>

<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.CreateDate" targetProperty="CreateTime"/>

</CriterionChoice>

• The label tag must refer to a display key

• The targetProperty attribute is required coon cocone ‘ccsdate
when adding new Options © since Last 365 days .
From @
* Including all option subelements on new to oo

CriterionChoice subelements

slides.title: Optional init attribute of CriterionChoice
slides.originalNotes:
Optional init attribute of CriterionChoice
The init tag of the CriterionChoice sub-element determines how the application displays the criteria. In the example shown, it determines:
The SearchType tag, TC CLAIM, determines what obj8ct is searched, from the SearchObjectType typelist
The Date SearchT ype tag, TC FROMLIST, determines that the "Since" option is selected, from the Date Search Type type list
The Date Range Choice tag, TC N365, determines that ZLaZt 365 days" is selected, from the Date Range Choice Type type list
The Chosen Option tag, Java. Criterion. Option-LossDat e, determines that the Loss Date option is selected in the Search For window.
slides.notes:
Optional init attribute of CriterionChoice
The init tag of the CriterionChoice sub-element determines how the application displays the criteria. In the example shown, it determines:
The SearchType tag, TC CLAIM, determines what obj8ct is searched, from the SearchObjectType typelist
The Date SearchT ype tag, TC FROMLIST, determines that the "Since" option is selected, from the Date Search Type type list
The Date Range Choice tag, TC N365, determines that ZLaZt 365 days" is selected, from the Date Range Choice Type type list
The Chosen Option tag, Java. Criterion. Option-LossDat e, determines that the Loss Date option is selected in the Search For window.
slides.ocrText:
Optional init attribute of CriterionChoice Gi

<CriterionChoice property="DateCriterionChoice”
init="DateCriterionChoice.SearchType = TC_CLAIM; DateCriterionChoice.DateSearchType = TC_FROMLIST;
DateCriterionChoice.DateRangeChoice = TC_N365; DateCriterionChoice.ChosenOption = équot;Java.Criterion.Option.Claim
+ LossDate&quot ;">
<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.LossDate" targetProperty="LossDate"/>
<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.ReportedDate" targetProperty="ReportedDate"/>
<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.CloseDate" targetProperty="CloseDate"/>
<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.CreateDate" targetProperty="CreateTime"/>
</CriterionChoice>

In this example, the init attribute specifies how to restrict the date field

* The user can restrict the date range either through a typelist of preset ranges
(such as next 30 days) or through a specific start and end date

* The init attribute sets the values

slides.title: ArrayCriterion (1 of 3)
slides.originalNotes:
ArrayCriterion (1 of 3)
The ArrayCriterion sub-element enables search on an array entity of the main entity. In the example shown, Claim's array of Officials is used to search on the official type. So, for example, you might search for a claim that had at least one Police officer associated with it.
The property tag is the name you assign to the ArrayCriterion.
The targetProperty is the name of the array on the search object — in this case, the Officials array on Claim.
The arrayMemberProperty is the name of the property to search for, not on the search object, but on the entity referenced by the array — in this case, the OfficialType on the Officials entity.
slides.notes:
ArrayCriterion (1 of 3)
The ArrayCriterion sub-element enables search on an array entity of the main entity. In the example shown, Claim's array of Officials is used to search on the official type. So, for example, you might search for a claim that had at least one Police officer associated with it.
The property tag is the name you assign to the ArrayCriterion.
The targetProperty is the name of the array on the search object — in this case, the Officials array on Claim.
The arrayMemberProperty is the name of the property to search for, not on the search object, but on the entity referenced by the array — in this case, the OfficialType on the Officials entity.
slides.ocrText:
| ArrayCriterion (1 of 3) Gi

• Instructs ClaimCenter to add a simple join against an array entity to the search
query
« For example, the Claim entity has an array of Officials
* So, you could add an ArrayCriterion that searched for officials of a given name or type
• Basic syntax:
<ArrayCriterion property="somename"
targetProperty="someTargetProperty"
arrayMemberProperty="propertyToMatchOnAnArrayMember" />

<ArrayCriterion
property="0fficials"
targetProperty="0fficials"
arrayMemberProperty="0fficialType"/>

slides.title: ArrayCriterion (2 of 3)
slides.originalNotes:
ArrayCriterion (2 of 3)
There are no optional tags, and you cannot specify any matchType; only equality is supported.
Note that there are no ArrayCriterion sub-elements in the base configuration of ClaimCenter- It is mostly used when an insurer creates a custom entity and wants to search based on it.
The arrayMemberProperty must be unique for each instance of the main search object — in the example, there should be more than one Official of any given type. (Since there in fact can be more than one official of any given type, this is actually a bad example.)
slides.notes:
ArrayCriterion (2 of 3)
There are no optional tags, and you cannot specify any matchType; only equality is supported.
Note that there are no ArrayCriterion sub-elements in the base configuration of ClaimCenter- It is mostly used when an insurer creates a custom entity and wants to search based on it.
The arrayMemberProperty must be unique for each instance of the main search object — in the example, there should be more than one Official of any given type. (Since there in fact can be more than one official of any given type, this is actually a bad example.)
slides.ocrText:
| ArrayCriterion (2 of 3)

All attributes are required
Supports equality matching only
* Therefore, you cannot specify a matchType attribute on ArrayCriteria
Is not used in the base application
* Most commonly used for joins to custom entities
The arrayMemberProperty cannot allow duplicate values

* Otherwise, the same target instance might appear multiple times in the search results

slides.title: ArrayCriterion (3 of 3)
slides.originalNotes:
ArrayCriterion (3 of 3)
Finally, you must create two indexes on the array table. The first index is based on the array object's foreign key back to the main search object, and the arrayMemberProperty which is being searched. The second index is based on the same properties in reverse order.
slides.notes:
ArrayCriterion (3 of 3)
Finally, you must create two indexes on the array table. The first index is based on the array object's foreign key back to the main search object, and the arrayMemberProperty which is being searched. The second index is based on the same properties in reverse order.
slides.ocrText:
| ArrayCriterion (3 of 3) Gi

Two indexes must be present on the array table.
« The first must be on the foreign key back to the main table and your chosen arrayMemberProperty
* The second must be on the same two properties but in the reverse order
(arrayMemberProperty first)
<index name="ind1" unique="true">
<indexCol name ="Claim" keyposition="1"/>
<indexCol name="0fficialType" keyposition="2"/>
</index>
<index name="ind2" unique="true">
<indexCol name="0fficialType" keyposition="1"/>
<indexCol name="Claim" keyposition="2"/>

</index>

slides.title: SearchCriteria entities
slides.originalNotes:
SearchCriteria entities
Just as you should not add any CriteriaDef sub-elements to search-config.xml, you should not add any SearchCriteria entities to ClaimCenter- These entities exist in a 1:1 relationship with the CriteriaDef sub-elements and determine what can be searched for in the main search entity.

You can, however, add a new column to search for — and, in fact, you must do so if you add anew column to search-config.xml.
slides.notes:
SearchCriteria entities
Just as you should not add any CriteriaDef sub-elements to search-config.xml, you should not add any SearchCriteria entities to ClaimCenter- These entities exist in a 1:1 relationship with the CriteriaDef sub-elements and determine what can be searched for in the main search entity.

You can, however, add a new column to search for — and, in fact, you must do so if you add anew column to search-config.xml.
slides.ocrText:
SearchCriteria entities Gi

• Every criteriaDef sub-element references by its ae
name a SearchCriteria entity Faut—_perentagedec

• These entities are created by Guidewire

« Do not create a new one

• When adding a new column to search for, you must
add the column to the searchcriteria

To search for a simple column on the target entity, create a boiny | AechivaDetncs atone
column

To search for a column which is a foreign key on the target
entity, create a foreign key

To search for a column which is a typekey on the target
entity, create a typekey

To search for an array on the target entity, create an array

slides.title: Configuring search in the UI
slides.originalNotes:
Configuring search in the UI
There is one key factor in configuring search that is different from most IJI configuration
slides.notes:
Configuring search in the UI
There is one key factor in configuring search that is different from most IJI configuration
slides.ocrText:
| Configuring search in the UI

Is pretty much like configuring anything else in the Ul,

except...

slides.title: Search using a search panel
slides.originalNotes:
Search using a search panel
Searching in ClaimCenter requires the use of a special IJI element called a SearchPanel. The SearchPanel typically includes a search detail view and a results list view.

Note that the creation of a search panel is quite complex and well beyond the limits of this course. I you need to create a new search panel, you should consult Guidewire Services.
slides.notes:
Search using a search panel
Searching in ClaimCenter requires the use of a special IJI element called a SearchPanel. The SearchPanel typically includes a search detail view and a results list view.

Note that the creation of a search panel is quite complex and well beyond the limits of this course. I you need to create a new search panel, you should consult Guidewire Services.
slides.ocrText:
| Search using a search panel

« Requires many complex properties
« Recommended you use existing search panels (and pages)

« If you must create a new search panel/page consult Guidewire Services

<SearchPanel
coriteriaNane="Searchcriteria”

.cabase. IQueryBeanResultélt;Regionégt;"

pickValue="CheckedValues"/>
</Toolbar>
</PanelRef>
</searchPane1>

slides.title: Search fields
slides.originalNotes:
Search fields
The detail view used for search has several input widgets, which refer to the search fields in the SearchCriteria entity referenced by the SearchPanel. You can add fields to the detail view.
Remember that the value properties of these widgets do not reference the search entity but the search criteria entity. Thus, if you are searching for
claim, you must reference th ClaimSearchCriteria in the widget's value property.
This means, in turn, that if you are searching for a new property, you must make sure that it exists on the relevant search criteria entity.
slides.notes:
Search fields
The detail view used for search has several input widgets, which refer to the search fields in the SearchCriteria entity referenced by the SearchPanel. You can add fields to the detail view.
Remember that the value properties of these widgets do not reference the search entity but the search criteria entity. Thus, if you are searching for
claim, you must reference th ClaimSearchCriteria in the widget's value property.
This means, in turn, that if you are searching for a new property, you must make sure that it exists on the relevant search criteria entity.
slides.ocrText:
Search fields Gi

• Appear in input sets in search panels

« Value for a search field must be a property of the appropriate SearchCriteria entity

slides.title: Required search fields
slides.originalNotes:
Required search fields
The coding to create the required search fields section of the detail view is very complex. Adding new sections, or adding and removing widgets from the existing DVs, is not supported.
slides.notes:
Required search fields
The coding to create the required search fields section of the detail view is very complex. Adding new sections, or adding and removing widgets from the existing DVs, is not supported.
slides.ocrText:
| Required search fields

• Required search fields (or groups of
fields) are set up by Guidewire

« You cannot add required search fields

* Attempting to do so is not supported by
Guidewire

• You should not remove required fields

« May have unexpected results

slides.title: Finally...
slides.originalNotes:
Finally.„
SOAP is an acronym for Simple Object Access Protocol, an XML standard for web services.

When you have finished configuring search, you must regenerate the APIs. Failure to do so means that the new search terms will appear in the IJI but will not be available to the search engine and may result in the server failing to start.
slides.notes:
Finally.„
SOAP is an acronym for Simple Object Access Protocol, an XML standard for web services.

When you have finished configuring search, you must regenerate the APIs. Failure to do so means that the new search terms will appear in the IJI but will not be available to the search engine and may result in the server failing to start.
slides.ocrText:
| Finally... G

Regenerate the SOAP and Java APIs.

1

a

. Open a command window.
2. Navigate to ../ClaimCenter.

3.

4. lf you have added any new fields to entities (other than the virtual

Run the command gwb genJavaApi.

SearchCriteria entities), also regenerate the Data Dictionary
« Run the command gwb genDataDict

Restart the ClaimCenter server.

6. Test your changes.

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
What sub-elements can a CriteriaDef element have?
•
•

questionData.question: What sub-elements can a CriteriaDef element have?
questionData.answer:
The correct answers are:
* Criterion
* CriterionChoice
* ArrayCriterion

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
What is special about the input widgets on a search page?
•
•

questionData.question: What is special about the input widgets on a search page?
questionData.answer:
The correct answer is they represent properties, not of the target entity, but of its
related Search Criteria entity.

slides.ocrText:

slides.title: To add new search capability in Contact Manager
slides.ocrText:
| To add new search capability in ContactManager Gi

1. Extend the ABContactSearchCriteria entity.

2. In search-config.xml, map aBContactSearchCriteria extensions to the ABContact
entity.

3. Modify the contact search criteria detail view so that new search criteria can be
specified.

4. Optionally modify the contact search results list view to display information about
your specified field.

5. Regenerate the Java and Soap APIs.

6. Restart the ContactManager server.

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
After adding a new search criterion to an existing search page, what
oo must be done?

questionData.question: After adding a new search criterion to an existing search page, what must be done?
questionData.answer:
The correct answer is:
Regenerate the SOAP and Java APIs.
Redeploy and restart the ClaimCenter server.
